title: How to Sew a Simple Pillow

steps.headline: Buy about one yard of fabric in a single color.
steps.description: If you want the two sides to be different, then buy a half a yard of each color and/or texture of fabric.

steps.headline: Measure a square to the size you want the pillow to be.
steps.description: Draw a template to this measurement on paper, to place over the fabric. Cut out the template, then pin it to the fabric. Cut out a piece of fabric based on the template. Remove the template and cut the other piece. Make sure that the two sides of the pillow cut out are the same size.

steps.headline: Take the fabric and match the sides that you want to show facing each other on the inside.
steps.description: You'll be sewing the inner part of the pillow first, then turning it inside out. This ensures both neatness of stitches and strength of the sewing. Pin together in readiness for stitching.

steps.headline: Sit at the sewing machine or grab your needle.
steps.description: Start sewing. As you sew around the edges, remove the pins from each stitched section.

steps.headline: Leave about 3 inches (7.6 cm) of the fabric open (which means don't sew that part).
steps.description: This leaves a hole for adding the stuffing of the pillow shortly.

steps.headline: Turn the stitched pillow inside out.
steps.description: The sides you want to be on show are now on the outside.

steps.headline: Fill the pillow with stuffing.
steps.description: Feed the stuffing through the open section of the pillow.

steps.headline: Sew the opening closed with a needle and thread.
steps.description: Be sure to knot it off tightly, to prevent unraveling. You can either finish here or add embellishments to the pillow as desired.

steps.headline: Finished.
steps.description: Put the pillow wherever you want it.

steps.headline: Select the fabric.
steps.description: You'll need one plain piece of fabric and one patterned or fancy piece of fabric measuring approximately 51cm (20 inches) square. In addition, get some piping cord for the edge of the pillow, measuring about 205cm (80 inches) in length.

steps.headline: Make a template of the pillow and use it to cut both the plain and patterned fabric.
Place the patterned fabric facing you.
Slip the piping cord inside the bias and place the cushion front with the piping right-side facing up.
Stitch a row of machine stitches around the edges to keep the piping in place.
steps.description: Stitch 6mm (1/3 inch) in from the seam. Continue sewing along one side of the pillow's open edge.

steps.headline: Place the plain fabric on top of the piping and patterned fabric.
steps.description: This means that the sides you want to show should face inward for now. Tack or pin the two pieces together, allowing for a 1.5cm/ 1/2 inch seam.

steps.headline: Sew the sides together, leaving enough space to slip the filling or cushion pad into the pillow.
Turn the cover right side facing out.
Slip the filling or cushion pad into the pillow through the open edge.
steps.description: Slip stitch the open edge to close firmly. Knot off tightly.

steps.headline: Plump the pillow.
steps.description: It is now ready for use. Given it has two different sides, you can switch sides to suit your mood or any décor changes.

text: Plain Simple Pillow Buy about one yard of fabric in a single color. If you want the two sides to be different, then buy a half a yard of each color and/or texture of fabric. Measure a square to the size you want the pillow to be. Draw a template to this measurement on paper, to place over the fabric. Cut out the template, then pin it to the fabric. Cut out a piece of fabric based on the template. Remove the template and cut the other piece. Make sure that the two sides of the pillow cut out are the same size. Take the fabric and match the sides that you want to show facing each other on the inside. You'll be sewing the inner part of the pillow first, then turning it inside out. This ensures both neatness of stitches and strength of the sewing. Pin together in readiness for stitching. Sit at the sewing machine or grab your needle. Start sewing. As you sew around the edges, remove the pins from each stitched section. Leave about 3 inches (7.6 cm) of the fabric open (which means don't sew that part). This leaves a hole for adding the stuffing of the pillow shortly. Turn the stitched pillow inside out. The sides you want to be on show are now on the outside. Fill the pillow with stuffing. Feed the stuffing through the open section of the pillow. Sew the opening closed with a needle and thread. Be sure to knot it off tightly, to prevent unraveling. You can either finish here or add embellishments to the pillow as desired. Finished. Put the pillow wherever you want it. Reversible Simple Pillow Select the fabric. You'll need one plain piece of fabric and one patterned or fancy piece of fabric measuring approximately 51cm (20 inches) square. In addition, get some piping cord for the edge of the pillow, measuring about 205cm (80 inches) in length. Make a template of the pillow and use it to cut both the plain and patterned fabric.  Place the patterned fabric facing you.  Slip the piping cord inside the bias and place the cushion front with the piping right-side facing up. Tuck firmly into the seam. Stitch a row of machine stitches around the edges to keep the piping in place. Stitch 6mm (1/3 inch) in from the seam. Continue sewing along one side of the pillow's open edge. Place the plain fabric on top of the piping and patterned fabric. This means that the sides you want to show should face inward for now. Tack or pin the two pieces together, allowing for a 1.5cm/ 1/2 inch seam. Sew the sides together, leaving enough space to slip the filling or cushion pad into the pillow.  Turn the cover right side facing out. Iron it flat. Slip the filling or cushion pad into the pillow through the open edge. Slip stitch the open edge to close firmly. Knot off tightly. Plump the pillow. It is now ready for use. Given it has two different sides, you can switch sides to suit your mood or any décor changes.
